ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOVERNMENT'S MOTION OF
CONFIDENCE
(Representation from U.K. Commissioner)


    1. Mr David Marshall (Anson) asked the Prime Minister whether he has received any representation from the United Kingdom Commissioner with reference to his speech made in the Assembly on 20th July, 1961, in support of his motion, "That this House expresses its confidence in the Government", and whether he will indicate its nature and contents.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said in my radio broadcast of 27th September this year - and I quote my words:

    "The British have more experience in dealing with such delicate situations. Whatever embarrassment our exposure caused them they have said absolute]y nothing and thereby saved themselves from further embarrassment."

    Ever since this broadcast, I have received no representation from the United Kingdom Commissioner with reference to my speech in this Assembly on 20th July.

Column: 31

MALAYSIA SOLIDARITY
CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE
(Appointment and expenses of Singapore delegate)


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister (a) who appointed the Member for Geylang Serai as a delegate of Singapore to the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee which met in Jesselton in August, 1961; and (b) whether the expenses of the Member for Geylang Serai in connection with his visit to Jesselton to attend that meeting were paid out of public funds and by what authority.

    The Prime Minister: The Member for Geylang Serai was appointed a delegate of Singapore to the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee which met in Jesselton in August 1961 by the Government Members of the Singapore delegation to the C.P.A. Conference in Singapore in July after discussion with

Column: 32

Opposition Member delegates to the same Conference. His expenses amounted to $596, and so did those of the Minister for Culture who also went to the Jesselton Conference. They were paid out of the Conference vote under Head 28, sub-head 10. This vote is under the control of the Ministry of Finance.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): The Prime Minister said that the Government Members consulted the Opposition Members. Did the Prime Minister realise that our Opposition Member, the Member for Choa Chu Kang, was never consulted?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, we would have saved ourselves a lot of trouble if Members of the new Barisan Sosialis Party had indicated their stand on the confidence motion on 20th July. We asked them where they stood: for or against the Government. They said they were not against the Government. Therefore they could not be the Opposition. Now they complain that, in fact, they were the Opposition and that they were not consulted. So they cannot have it both ways. Now that they are clearly in the Opposition, if there is to be any consultation, we shall take in the Member for Queenstown.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I refer to what the Prime Minister has said just now. Although I took part in the C.P.A. Conference, I was not invited to discuss the question of representatives. Therefore, the Government did not have a discussion with us regarding the choice of representatives to the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee.

    Mr Speaker: I think I must make it clear that we are on supplementary questions. We are not debating this question. But if the hon. Member has a supplementary question, he can ask it.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew)(In Mandarin): On the 20th of July, at a sitting of this Assembly when we debated the motion of confidence in the Government, the Member for Choa Chu Kang did not indicate that he was against the Government; so we presumed that he supported it. It was only on the 31st of October

Column: 33

that we knew he went over to the Opposition. The meeting was held in August without inviting him, because he did not seek contact with us. Therefore, we were not responsible for that.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin (Nee Soon): Mr Speaker, Sir, is it the contention of the Prime Minister that all Assemblymen on the Government Benches will automatically agree with Government policies whether in principle or in minute details - and that without consulting them at the beginning, he can assume that they have agreed with all his policies? If that were so -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member is going a little too far. We are now dealing with the appointment of a representative to the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee. If he has a supplementary question on that, he may ask it, but not on the wider implications of policy and so on.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): A Minister of the Government should take notice that he should hold consultations with the others.

    Mr Speaker: There again I think we are perhaps entering into a debate. There does not seem to be any supplementary question to be answered.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew)(In Mandarin): I think our Party Whip has carried out his duty. Of course, he has to inform all Members concerned.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Did the Prime Minister inform the President of the C.P.A. about the matter?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I was on leave at that moment, and the Acting Prime Minister was the Leader of the House. I do not think he was in any way connected with the C.P.A. delegates to this Conference.

    Mr Speaker: I think we have had enough of debate. If any hon. Member wishes to raise the question, he will have an opportunity either on the adjournment or in a motion.

LEAVE OF ABSENCE OF
MINISTERS
(Particulars)


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister (a) whether any Minister has taken leave of absence from his duties since the last sitting of the Second Session of this Assembly, giving the name of the Minister, the period of leave and the provisions under which such leave was granted; and (b) whether any Minister on leave of absence, has received or will be receiving remuneration and allowance as a Minister for the period of leave and under what provision of the law.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Since the last sitting of the Second Session of this Assembly, the following Ministers have taken leave of absence under section 33 of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council:-

    The Prime Minister - from 25th July to 24th October.

    The Minister for Health - from 24th July to 22nd September.

    The Minister for Home Affairs - from 22nd July to 15th September.

Column: 35



    The Minister for Finance - from 3rd September to 15th September.

    The Minister for Culture - from 23rd September to 8th October.

    The Minister for National Development - from 23rd October to 29th October.

    When a Minister is on leave, including the Prime Minister, one of his colleagues in the Cabinet acts for him. No Minister is paid any acting allowance. All Ministers receive remuneration as Ministers for the leave period. This was also the case from the time the Member for Anson was Chief Minister of the then Singapore Government.

Column: 35

MALAY MARKET IN GEYLANG


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will consider acquiring a site and building a market for Malay stallholders in the Geylang area.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on the 7th of December, 1960, the Government approved a plan for a comprehensive redevelopment of the site in Geylang Serai for community purposes. There will be provision for a school with playgrounds, a community centre, housing, local shopping and market, and two open market areas. Land acquisition proceedings are on the way.

    The allocation of stalls will be by the Markets and Hawkers Department and will take into account the fact that this is largely a Malay area patronised by Malays in the Kampong Melayu and Geylang Serai areas. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the majority of stallholders are expected to be Malays.

EXERCISE OF POWERS UNDER
PRESERVATION OF
PUBLIC SECURITY ORDINANCE,
1955
(Requests by Federation Government to Singapore Government)


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether any requests have been made by the Government of the Federation of Malaya to the Singapore Government in regard to the

Column: 36

exercise of the powers under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955, in respect of any individual or group of individuals and if he will state the terms of any such requests.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, there are no requests made by the Federation of Malaya Government to the Singapore Government in regard to the exercise of powers under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. All matters of internal security provided under Part VII of the Constitution are decided in the Internal Security Council.

Column: 36

COMMUNIST ACTIVITIES
IN SINGAPORE
(Request for statement)


    7. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Prime Minister whether he will make a statement disclosing the full details, within his knowledge, giving names and identities, etc., of Communists and Communist subversive activities in Singapore, and his dealings with them and their activities.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I have, in my first series of broadcasts, sketched in broad outline my personal knowledge of the activities of the Communists and pro-Communists in Singapore. In some cases, I have had to name the persons involved in order that the truth may be known and not disputed. It is not my intention, however, to go on a witch-hunt and label all the Communists I know personally. However, certain organisations like S.A.T.U., Partai Rakyat, and some members of the Barisan Sosialis, have challenged me to prove that they are Communist front organisations. Sir, I am accepting their invitation and will do so in my second series of broadcasts.

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    The Prime Minister: So far as is possible, I do not wish to identify publicly the persons that I have known. It is only when not to name these persons would leave a blank in the whole picture and allow the Communists to try and cast doubts on the truth and veracity of my statements that I shall name

Column: 37

the persons who are actually performing or directing these Communist activities. All such persons named publicly will have full rights under the law to clear themselves and their reputation.

    Mr David Marshall: If it pleases you, Sir, in view of the fact that to be a Communist is a criminal offence in this area, will the Prime Minister not recognise that it is the duty of a citizen, even more so the Prime Minister, to make known his knowledge of all Communists in this area, at least to the police for purposes of prosecution under our laws?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I think the Member for Anson, as the first Chief Minister of Singapore, is fully alive to the tremendous difficulty that is posed by the silent intimidation of the Communists and their elimination squads of any witness who goes into open court, or even in camera. I have, therefore, given the Communists an opportunity to allow them to initiate action against the Government and against myself personally for having damaged their fair names if they say that they arc innocent. Doubtless they may also have consulted their multifarious legal advisers and advisers. Some of these advisers have only passed Parts of the Law Examination. However, they may well understand that to challenge statements made of them would be to undergo the rigours of being plaintiffs and giving evidence in person.

    Sir, as the Member for Anson can well vouchsafe from his law and very intimate knowledge of Court craft, an innocent man telling the truth can prove his innocence at any time, particularly since he has available to him the whole panoply of the law, the best advocates in the land. Some of them, I am sure, are prepared to do a brief for nothing in order that justice will be done. I regret to say, however, that apart from one proceeding in relation to contempt of court by some 30-odd non-Communist strikers, there has not been any action on any part of the talks that I have delivered, I would ask the

Column: 38

Member for Anson to draw his own conclusion - 30 innocent strikers who are now under charge of obstruction are quite prepared to assert their rights if I have transgressed the law and I have to submit as if I were a private citizen. So also can all the others who say they are innocent. They have their remedies. They can consult their advisers and they can undergo the hazards of the open confrontation.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, could one anti-Communist hero, like our Prime Minister, get on so well with the so-called Communists in Singapore for the last six years?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, that is the whole point - that I was never an anti-Communist in the sense that I was just anti the Communists. I am a firm supporter of the democratic system. In so far as the Communists were with us in the nationalist movement to destroy the colonial system, I was prepared to work with them and took my risk with them for years. And they knew it. But when their policy is no longer to destroy the colonial system in order that the democratic system can be set up. but to undermine the State in order to establish a base from which they can communize the whole of Malaya, then I say that the non-Communists and the pro-Communists must inevitably part company. Co-existence, Mr Speaker, Sir, whether it be on a domestic and national level or on the august plane of international relations, can only continue if there are no massive issues which divide them. Mr Nehru is not an anti-Communist, but that did not prevent him from standing up for what he considered to be his national rights over the borders of India against the Communists, co-existence notwithstanding. Sir, we had served notice, the day we moved the confidence motion, that we intend to see merger and an independent, democratic Malaya through. And those who want to fight us - be they Communists or whatever they may be - cannot expect us to submit passively and be pulverized. Surely, Sir, the most fundamental right a man has is that of self-defence. A non-Communist does not subscribe to self-destruction.

Column: 39

Only fools do that. Sir, if there are still fools in Singapore or, if I may be so bold as to suggest, in this Assembly who are non-Communists and who want to go with them and be destroyed, what can we do to save them from their own folly?

    Mr David Marshall: Do forgive me, Sir, it is rather an important matter. I crave your indulgence. Sir, I can appreciate the Prime Minister's difficulty about prosecution. He is perfectly right. But I would suggest that it is a matter of very considerable importance to the public as a whole that the names of the persons whom he knows actually to be Communists in this territory should be disclosed. If the Prime Minister will permit me, Sir, I myself as Chairman of the Workers' Party am to some extent concerned, because it was suggested that my Party was infiltrated by Communists.

    Mr Speaker: A supplementary question?

    Mr David Marshall: It is, Sir. I would point out, Sir, that we had sought from the Prime Minister information -

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the hon. Member for Anson goes on in that strain, then I must stop him.

    Mr David Marshall: May I -

    Mr Speaker: Will the Member resume his seat?

    Mr Marshall resumed his seat.

    Mr Speaker: I was saying that if the hon. Member goes on in that strain then, of course, the whole matter is developing into a debate, and the Standing Orders tell me that that should not be allowed. I can only allow supplementary questions, and I leave it to the ingenuity of Members to turn their statements into supplementary questions.

    Mr David Marshall: Sir, will the Prime Minister consider divulging in confidence to persons legitimately interested the names of the Communists who are known to him who might affect such persons?

Column: 40



    The Prime Minister: Sir, the Member for Anson, as the Chairman of the Workers' Party, wrote to me and asked me to disclose the Communist cadres who had been planted in the Workers' Party. I have consulted the legality of this matter. I have written to the Chairman of the Workers' Party in reply that if he, who was the first Chief Minister of Singapore in 1955, would give us an undertaking that he would not divulge this information to the Communists concerned and the details of the data we had on them, then I am prepared to ask the State Advocate-General to waive the Official Secrets Act and disclose to the Member for Anson all data in connection with Communists in his Party. The offer is made in good faith. I am confident that any undertaking given by the Member for Anson will be honoured and I think the State Advocate-General will also be confident of that.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin (Nee Soon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was extremely interested to hear the Prime Minister say that only fools embark on political self-destruction. If that definition is true, Sir, the corollary is also true - that anybody who embarks upon self-destruction is a fool. The clearest way of determining whether one is embarking upon self-extermination is by going to the country and letting the people decide.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Then you can see -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have indicated that only supplementary questions are allowed. I think this matter is developing into a debate. If any Member is interested, there are ways in which the whole matter could be debated in this Chamber. The matter is now closed.

    It is 3.00 p.m. - Committee of Supply.

THIRD SUPPLEMENTARY
ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE
FOR 1961


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

Column: 41

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



3.01 p.m.

    The Chairman: Third Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1961 (Paper Cmd. 29 of 1961). Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of these Supplementary Estimates?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

    The Chairman: The summary is in the last page. Head 42, Official Assignee and Public Trustee. There is an amendment standing in the name of the Member for Anson.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 42 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1.

    Mr Speaker. Sir, you will notice that these Supplementary Estimates are required to meet the increases under Personal Emoluments as a result of partial restoration of variable allowances from the 1st of January this year and full restoration from the 1st of September. That is not the total figure, Sir. The total figure is much greater. But the rest are offset seemingly by savings to meet the increases.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, since this Government took office, the issue of the variable allowances of civil servants has been made a headache - a headache for the Assembly, a headache for the people, and most of all, Sir, a headache for the civil service and particularly 6,000 of them.

    In moving this amendment, I am seeking to ask the Government to consolidate the variable allowances into the pay of the civil service, so that there can be no further reductions. I am not asking that they should receive one cent more of salary.

    All I want is to take the question of the pay of the civil servants out of politics. Sir, they are entitled to security; they are the very backbone of our administration. In fairness I think the Government will admit our civil service has been reasonably efficient. And frankly, Sir, I know of no other civil

Column: 42

service in the whole of Asia with such a high standard of integrity. In many cases, I think the Government will frankly admit that the civil servants are radically underpaid compared to the responsibilities we place upon them. It is important that these human beings, from whom we expect so much, should at least have a sense of security free from the possibility of political intimidation.

    I intend to be brief, Sir, but I ask your indulgence to review shortly the history of P.A.P. dealings with the civil service on this one aspect of variable allowances.

    In June 1959, Sir, this Government took office through an overwhelming vote of the people of Singapore, but it was generally recognised that the English-speaking population, in all probability, did not vote for the P.A.P., particularly the civil service. Before this Government even appeared before the Assembly, one of the very first steps it took was to slash the variable allowance of the civil service. And in His Excellency's speech to this House outlining Government policy on the 1st of July, 1959, he said:

    `The threatened deficit of S14 million for 1959 can he and will be wiped out and the Government has not shrunk from unpleasant measures to achieve financial stability. But such sacrifices as have been imposed by way of pay cuts have fallen on those most able to hear them.'

My reference, Sir, for your record is Assembly Debates, Vol. 11 No 1. Col. 6.

    `Those most able to bear them', Mr Speaker! How little did the Government recognise that of all our citizens, the honest civil servants are the ones who budget most carefully according to their incomes, and any radical reduction means very real hardship. In any event, Sir, as was pointed by the Leader of the S.P.A. in the debate on the Address in the following year, on the 8th August, 1960, it transpired that there was no $14 million deficit. There was not even a $1 million deficit. There was $9 million surplus.

    Even if it can be said, Sir, that the Finance Minister did really make so big an error as $23 million in his estimate in our inevitably small budget, why did the Government not restore the pay cuts the moment it was recognised that

Column: 43

Singapore was not going bankrupt? That Singapore, in fact, was stable and was doing very well? In fact, there was a surplus and not a deficit. Why did they not restore the pay cuts? In fact, Sir, the leader of the S.P.A. - more credit to him - moved in this Assembly, on the 8th of August, for the restoration of the pay cuts. But the Government, using its steamroller majority, defeated that motion. Sir, it is interesting to remember that in this very Assembly, on 21st July, 1959, the Prime Minister said:

    `What they are bellyaching about is not the principle of negotiations. The bellyache is the pay cut.'

The civil servant could not even moderately and constitutionally and legitimately complain about a pay cut without being called a "bellyacher". That was the attitude of the Government, and, in fairness. Sir, it is true to say that in those debates, as I have read them in Hansard, Government vehemently denied that the pay cuts were by way of revenge against the English-educated for not having voted for the P.A.P. But, Sir, what do we see now? From 1st January, after tremendous efforts, a partial restoration: first to those who agreed that that would be final; then ultimately to all. And then, Sir, lo and behold, a miracle happened! The pay cuts were restored in full from the 1st of September. And His Excellency, in his speech to us last month, said that with merger in prospect it is possible to relax many of the stringent measures of economy previously adopted. With "merger in prospect" also, Sir, a vast sum of money will no doubt be voted to the Federation, and we would have less money to spend. But be that as it may, Sir, merger is two and a half years ahead, if, and I hope with all my heart it does, come to merger. Why is it that the Government is in such a hurry to restore the pay cuts now? Sir, in this context, let us face another fact of life. In 1959, the Government could say, "We do not care about the English-educated. It is the Chinese industrialists who will vote us into power." And they did.

    The Prime Minister: The industrial workers, not the industrialists.

Column: 44



    Mr David Marshall: Thank you. I am indebted to the Prime Minister. He recognises the P.A.P. stand so well. He has aptly and correctly corrected me. I accept it. "We do not care about the English-speaking; it is the Chinese industrial workers who will vote us into power." And they did. Today the Prime Minister and, I have no doubt, the rest of his group are all too conscious that they have lost the confidence of the Chinese industrial workers. And if they hope to survive, it is the English-educated on whom they are to rely. Sir, whatever the motivations of the Government, I would suggest that their conduct does give rise to feelings, and legitimate feelings, of fear, intimidation and insecurity on the part of the civil service. I plead, Sir, let us put an end to this.

    I do not want them to worry next time we have a general election, having learnt their lesson, if they vote P.A.P. and suddenly the S.P.A. come into power - and miracles do happen - may be they will get another thrashing. Let us protect the civil service, legitimate protection which an honest. decent group seeks. Many of them could earn far more in the outside world. They join the civil service sometimes out of a sense of dedication, but mostly, Sir, because of their desire for security. And I say, let us protect the civil service from a legitimate deep fear that has grown from government action of possible intimidation. I say, let us help keep the civil service out of politics. We all recognise that that is the only way in which they can serve the country best. I, therefore, move this amendment in order to urge the Government to consolidate the pay cuts, not to pay the civil service more.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought the motion to amend the vote under Head 42 by the Member for Anson was, in fact, related to the administration of the Office of the Official Assignee and Public Trustee.
